normalised: So, someone asked about planning a big event in India, right? Figuring out the date and time can be a real headache, especially with all the auspicious timings and family schedules. For a wedding, for instance, the Pandit ji usually suggests dates based on the couple's birth charts. My cousin's wedding got pushed back by six months just because the original date, twenty third May two thousand and twenty four, wasn't considered lucky enough!

unnormalised: Then there's the weather to consider. If it's an outdoor event, avoid the peak of summer (April-June) in most of India, or the monsoon season (July-September) in places like Mumbai or Kerala. October to March is generally a safer bet. And if you are thinking about a corporate event around Diwali, which falls on 01/11/2024 this year, booking venues and caterers way in advance is a must! Everything gets super busy and prices go up.

unnormalised: Finally, think about travel and holidays. Avoid clashing with major exams or festivals if you're expecting guests from out of town. A lot of people travel during holidays like Holi (17/03/2025) or Republic Day (26/01). Also, try to finalize the time ASAP; sending invites just 2 weeks before 15/12, for example, might mean half your guest list is unavailable!
